"Itâ€™s nothing", replied the dog, "This is just the spot where the collar rubs against my neck when Iâ€™m chained up at night. Itâ€™s not that bad once you get used to it." "If that is all,", said the wolf, "then I would rather return to the forest."
fable2: A young ox lived on a small farm where the farmer worked him hard but fed him well. One day the ox saw a herd of wild buffalo galloping freely across the plains. That night, he broke out of his pen and joined them. Though he often went hungry now, roaming the prairies with the buffalo was far better than his previous life of well-fed servitude. The ox soon realized that freedom, however lean, is sweeter than a full belly in captivity.

fable1: Two pots were carried downstream by a river, one made of clay and the other made of brass. The clay pot said to the brass one: "Please stay far away from me, as I will break into pieces if we collide. I will do my best to avoid you, as well."
fable2: A lion and a tiger lived in the same jungle. Though they were both big cats, the lion always boasted he was king of the jungle. The tiger grew tired of the lion's boasting. One day, the tiger challenged the lion to a contest to decide who was really the best. After a long struggle, neither emerged as the clear winner. Exhausted from their fight, the lion and tiger realized they were equals in strength and ferocity. From that day forward, they became the best of friends and partners, watching over the jungle together.

fable1: In his search for food, the grasshopper came across a chrysalis that was very near its time of change. The chrysalis moved its tail attracting the grasshopperâ€™s attention, who initially didnâ€™t think that it was a living being. "What a sad life you live, strange creature", remarked the grasshopper, "While I can jump around at my leisure, you are trapped within your shell and unable to move more than your scaly tail." The chrysalis heard the unpleasant comments but did not reply. A couple of days later, the grasshopper came by the chrysalis again, but only found an empty shell. Wondering what happened, he suddenly felt himself shaded and fanned by the beautiful wings of a gorgeous butterfly. "It is I, your much-pitied friend!", said the butterfly to the grasshopper, "Please boast again of your superiority, but only as long as you can reach me." Having said that, the butterfly rose to the sky and was soon invisible to the grasshopper.
fable2: A wolf decided he wanted to eat some of the sheep that lived on a nearby farm. He covered himself with wool and walked on four legs so he would look like a sheep. The farmer was surprised when he saw the "sheep" walking on all fours but didn't think much of it. That night, the wolf snuck into the barn where the sheep slept. In the dark, none of the sheep noticed that he was not really one of them. After the lights went out, the "sheep" attacked! The next morning, the farmer came to find half his flock gone. From then on, he kept a closer eye on all his sheep, knowing that appearances could be deceiving.

fable1: A masterful archer decided to hunt in the mountains, but every animal that he encountered fled at his approach. Only the tiger stood his ground. The archer immediately shot an arrow at the tiger, saying: "Iâ€™m only sending you a messenger. But he will let you know what to expect when I attack you personally." The wounded tiger fled fearing for his life and hid in his cave. A raccoon who happened to see the whole spectacle unfold, told the tiger that he shouldnâ€™t have backed off after the very first attack. But the tiger replied: "Your words mean nothing to me. How can I possibly fight someone who sends such a terrifying message?"
fable2: A lion was stalking prey on the savanna. He crept slowly through the tall grass, eyes fixed on a zebra grazing nearby. Just as the lion prepared to pounce, a sharp pain pierced his side. The lion collapsed, an arrow lodged in his ribs. A hunter had shot him from a hidden vantage point far away. The zebra, startled by the lion’s cries, galloped to safety. As the lion bled out, he realized he should have watched more carefully for danger from afar. The savanna fell silent as the lion breathed his last breath. The hunter emerged to claim his prized trophy.

fable1: One day, a donkey found a tigerâ€™s skin left behind by a group of hunters to dry in the sun. The donkey decided to put the skin on and head to the nearest village. Animals and humans alike fled as he approached, which filled him with such pride that he began to bray. Once everyone realized that this tiger was, in fact, a donkey, his owner gave him a solid beating for the terror he caused the villagers.
fable2: The fox was walking through the forest one day when he came upon a flock of sheep. He noticed that one sheep was wearing a fine wool coat and fancy hat. "My friend, you look so distinguished today!" said the fox. The sheep replied "Yes, I found these lovely clothes by the stream. Aren't they marvelous?" The fox smiled slyly. "Indeed, they are quite impressive. In fact, I think they make you look very wise." The sheep beamed with pride. "Why thank you! I knew such elegant clothes would make me look intelligent." At that, the fox pounced and gobbled up the foolish sheep.

fable1: It is said that a monkey has two kids at each birth. One is fondled and nurtured by his mother, receiving the greatest affection, while the other is hated and neglected. Once, it happened that the favourite child was smothered by the overpowering love of his parent, while the hated child prospered in spite of the neglect that he experienced.
fable2: A young bird was eager to learn how to fly. Each morning, he climbed to the highest branch of a tall tree. The little bird flapped his wings as hard as he could, hoping this time he would soar through the sky. But each time, despite his efforts, he tumbled down through the branches, eventually landing with a soft thud in the grass below. The little bird was frustrated but refused to give up. He continued climbing the tree and trying to fly day after day. Though his intentions were good, the little bird's wings were simply not yet strong enough for flight.

fable1: Desiring to have a ruler, the toads send ambassadors to Zeus, asking him to grant their wish. Thus, Zeus placed a log into the toadsâ€™ pond, assuming that it would suffice for such simple creatures. Initially terrified of the log, the toads soon realized that it remained motionless and posed no danger. Seeing the log as unfit to be their ruler, the toads petitioned Zeus once more. Thus, he sent an eel to govern them. As the eel was good-natured and made no demands of the toads, they felt misunderstood by the deity and once again asked him to provide them with a proper ruler. Annoyed, Zeus sent a heron to live in their pond, who soon ate all of the toads.
fable2: A farmer owned a small plot of land that yielded just enough crops to feed his family. One day he decided he wanted more, so he cleared the surrounding forest to plant more crops. At first the expanded fields produced abundant harvests. But without the forest, rainfall declined, and his unprotected topsoil eroded. Eventually the land became barren. His original small field had been just enough to sustain his family. But in his greed for more, he ruined what he had. Now their future was uncertain.

fable1: A birch tree boasted to a shrub, "My wood is valuable and is used everywhere in roofs and walls of houses, while you have no use whatsoever." The shrub replied: "Had you considered the axes and saws that are used to harvest your wood, I think you'll end up wishing to be a useless shrub like me."
fable2: There was once a poor farmer who lived in a small hut with his family. Though they had little, they were joyful and cared for one another deeply. One day, the farmer found riches buried on his land. He moved his family into a grand house and bought fine clothes and food. But in their new life of wealth, they grew selfish and stopped caring for each other. The farmer realized that his family's love had made their poor life rich, while riches without care left them poor inside. So they moved back to their small hut and were happy again in their life of loving poverty.

fable1: A toad left his home in the marsh and moved to the forest, where he introduced himself to the animals as a skilled doctor able to heal any disease. Doubting such bold proclamations, the raccoon asked: "How can you claim to be such an excellent doctor if youâ€™re unable to heal your own wrinkled skin and lame gait?"
fable2: The village doctor was known far and wide for his ability to cure any ailment. One day, the doctor came down with a terrible cough. He tried every remedy he knew, but nothing seemed to help. As the cough persisted, the doctor became increasingly frustrated. How could he heal others but not himself? Finally, the doctor realized he had overlooked the obvious - sometimes the physician needs healing too. He rested and took care of himself until the cough passed. When he resumed seeing patients, he did so with more empathy and patience.

fable1: In an attempt to escape a pack of pursuing dogs, a stag fled inside a stable and hid himself in a pile of hay, with only the tips of his horns visible to the outside. Soon, the stable was visited by hunters trailing their dogs. They asked the stable boys, who were resting after their dinner, if they had seen a stag, but looking around the stable, neither were able to spot the stag. After some time, the master of the stable came in and, pointing at the pile of hay, asked what the two strange things sticking out of it were. When the stable boys examined the pile, they quickly discovered the stag and killed him.
fable2: A young fox was hunting in the forest when he came across a plump rabbit. Seeing an easy meal, the fox crept up slowly, getting ready to pounce. Just as he leapt towards the rabbit, it darted away into the bushes. Confused, the fox looked around and saw the old owl perched in a nearby tree, having warned the rabbit just in time. The fox cursed under his breath and stalked away, his empty stomach growling. Though he had been careful and quiet, the watchful owl had noticed his approach and ruined his hunt. The fox resolved to be more observant himself next time, for he now knew that little ever escapes the wise old owl's notice.

fable1: Lying on his deathbed, an old man summoned his children to give them one last piece of advice. He asked his servant to collect a bundle of sticks and give it to his eldest son. "Try to break it.", the old man said. The son tried his best, but was unable to break the bundle. Neither could any of the other children. Seeing this, the man asked them to untie the sticks and each take and break a single stick, which was easily accomplished. "This is my final lesson for you.", said the man.
fable2: A flock of small birds lived in a forest. One day, a hawk began hunting them. Each bird the hawk targeted was too weak to fight it alone. So the birds banded together and flew in a tight formation. Whenever the hawk approached, the entire flock worked together to distract it and chase it away. Though individually powerless, their unity made them strong. The frustrated hawk eventually left to seek easier prey. From then on, the birds stuck together, and the hawk never bothered them again. Their union had made them mighty.

fable1: A thief tried to break into a house during the night and brought with him some sausages to appease the house dog and keep him from barking. As the thief threw the sausages towards the dog, he addressed the intruder as follows: "Do not think that those will stop me from raising my voice. I am now even more weary of you, as your kind gesture likely serves your own goals which will, ultimately, cause trouble for me and my master."
fable2: A fox was walking through the woods when he came upon a hunter's trap. The fox's leg was caught in the trap. A rabbit hopped by and saw the fox's predicament. "I can free you from the trap if you promise not to eat me," said the rabbit. Eager to be free, the fox readily agreed. The rabbit freed the fox from the trap. As soon as he was loose, the fox turned and chased the rabbit. The rabbit barely escaped into his burrow. The fox licked his chops, frustrated that his lunch had gotten away.

fable1: A man agreed to buy a donkey from his owner under the condition that he could try the animal out first. Thus, he brought the donkey to his home and put him in the stable together with his other donkeys. The new arrival ignored most of his new brethren, quickly joining the most idle of them who was also the greatest eater. Witnessing this, the man quickly took the donkey back to his owner and withdrew his offer. This surprised the owner who asked how the man could decide this so quickly. "I know that the donkey will not be different from the one he chose to befriend in my stable.", replied the man.
fable2: A young fox was eager to make new friends in the forest. He came across a pack of wolves who invited him to hunt with them that night. Excited to belong, the fox joined the wolves as they raided a nearby farm, stealing chickens and vandalizing the farmhouse. The next morning, the farmer saw the damage and set traps to catch the culprits. That evening, the fox returned with the wolves to cause more trouble. But this time, one of the wolves was caught in a trap. The fox fled in fear, realizing too late that the troublemaking wolves were not the type of friends worth having. From then on, the fox was more careful when choosing companions.

fable1: In a garden, a rose grew next to an amaranth. One day, the amaranth said to her neighbor: "Your beauty and sweet scent are to be envied! Iâ€™m not surprised that you are beloved by all.". The rose replied, with sadness in her voice: "My friend, my bloom only lasts for a short while. Eventually, my petals will wither and I will perish. You, on the other hand, are everlasting, as your flowers do not fade even when cut."
fable2: The lion was king of the jungle. All the animals feared and respected him. Every day, they brought him tributes of food. The lion soon grew bored of the easy meals. He longed for the thrill of the hunt. So he announced he would no longer accept tributes. The other animals cheered, no longer having to sacrifice for the lion. But soon the lion grew hungry. His greatness as king carried the penalty of having to work for his food.

fable1: In his attempt to cross a rapid river, the raccoon was swept away by the strong current and carried into a deep ravine, where he remained unable to move due to his injuries. A swarm of blood-sucking flies soon found him and descended onto his skin. Some time later, the raccoon was discovered by a sparrow, who asked if she should scare away the flies that were tormenting him. Weakly, the raccoon replied: "Please do not disturb them. The flies that you see have drunk plenty of my blood and no longer sting me much. If you scare them away, new flies will arrive who are hungry and will suck me dry."
fable2: A poor man struggled to feed his family. Though he worked hard, he earned little. A rich merchant traveled through town flaunting his wealth. The poor man eyed the merchant's heavy coin purse and thought of his hungry children. That night, the poor man snuck out and stole the merchant's purse, knowing it held more coins than he could spend in a year. The next morning, the merchant shook his head at the loss of his purse but knew his wealth would allow him to easily buy another. Meanwhile, the poor man hurried home, poured out the stolen coins, and rejoiced that his family would now be fed.

fable1: A hawk was tracking a rabbit while perching on a tree branch, preparing to swoop down and catch her. At the same time, a bowman hidden in the bushes released an arrow at the hawk, piercing his heart. As he was dying, the hawk noticed that the feathers adorning the arrow were his own and lamented: "How tragic that I must die of an arrow that would not exist without my help."
fable2: The farmer worked hard to grow a bountiful crop of corn. When it ripened, he was proud of the tall, golden stalks. But he left his barn doors open at night to let in the cool breeze. One evening, a hungry fox slipped inside. She gorged herself on the corn and scurried away before dawn. In the morning, the farmer was heartbroken to find his precious crop half-eaten. He had supplied the fox exactly what she needed to ruin his harvest. From then on, he kept the barn shut tight at night. Though it meant sleeping in stuffy air, it protected the rest of his crop.

fable1: A coyote spent a great deal of time trying to snatch one of the sheep away from the flock, but kept failing due to the watchful shepherd and his dogs. One day, he found a sheepskin that was left in the sun to dry and threw it over his own pelt, allowing him to walk among the sheep undetected. Eventually, a lamb recognized the skin as belonging to her mother and started to follow the coyote, who led her apart from the flock and ate her.
fable2: A hungry fox wandered into a vineyard and saw a cluster of ripe, red grapes hanging high above him. Wanting to eat them, he jumped up to grab the grapes, but they were just out of reach. He tried again and again, but could not reach the grapes. Exhausted from jumping, the fox gave up and walked away, remarking, "Those grapes are probably sour anyway." In truth, the grapes looked ripe and delicious, but the fox convinced himself they must be sour to justify giving up. Though their appearance was sweet and tempting, it did not match the fox's experience of failure.

fable1: In an unlikely turn of events, a raccoon befriended a hawk and both decided to live in the same tree. The hawk built a nest in its upper branches, while the raccoon found a home in the underwood and started a family. Not long after, the raccoon left to procure food for her children, which the hawk took as an opportunity to do the same and seized one of the kits to feed to her own brood. Upon returning, the raccoon was saddened to find one of her children missing but was even more aggrieved that she couldnâ€™t avenge its death. The hawk, however, soon received an appropriate punishment. One day, she spotted villagers sacrificing a sheep on an altar and swooped down to steal some of the meat, carrying it back to her nest along with a burning cinder. The cinder grew into a flame fanned by the strong winds at the top of the tree, setting the nest on fire and burning the fledglings to a crisp. As they fell to the ground, the raccoon ate them up in clear view of the hawk.
fable2: A young fox was walking through the forest when he came upon a rabbit trapped in a hunter's snare. The fox thought, "If I were caught in a trap, I would want someone to set me free." So he gnawed at the snare until the rabbit was able to hop away. The next day, the fox's leg was caught in another hunter's trap. The rabbit came upon the trapped fox and remembered how the fox had rescued him. So the rabbit chewed through the snare, setting the fox free. From that day forward, the fox and rabbit became friends, helping each other whenever they were in need.

fable1: The hares were engaged in a one-sided war with the wolves and asked the raccoons for their help. An emissary of the raccoons replied: "We would have loved to help you, if only we didnâ€™t know who you are and who your enemy is."
fable2: A young bird was eager to leave the nest and take his first flight. Ignoring his mother's warnings, he leapt from the tree branch before his wings were strong enough. He flapped and flailed, but couldn't gain altitude. The ground rushed up to meet him. Though the fall was short, the impact broke his wing. For the rest of the season, he had to watch his siblings fly and play while he remained grounded. His eagerness had led to injury that could have been avoided by patiently waiting a bit longer. Now each day he dutifully exercised his healing wing, dreaming of the day he too could finally soar.

fable1: By accident, a raccoon fell into a deep well without any way to get out again. Soon, a sheep came to the same well, intending to quench her thrust. There, she saw the raccoon and asked whether the water was good to drink. The raccoon praised the water as being of highest quality and encouraged the sheep to come down and try for herself, which she quickly did. Once she was equally stuck at the bottom of the well, the raccoon proposed a way for them to escape together: "If you stand against the wall on your hind legs, I will run up your back and escape. Afterwards I will help you out, too." The sheep agreed and allowed the raccoon to climb on top of her, who was thus able to reach the mouth of the well. Once outside, he started running away as fast as he could, leaving the sheep behind. As the sheep cursed at him for breaking his promise, the raccoon retorted: "You fool, had you thought first, you would have never gotten yourself into a situation from which you could not escape, nor enabled me to take a path to freedom that you could not follow."
fable2: A hungry fox was wandering through the forest when he spotted a rabbit hopping along the path. Licking his chops, the fox crept slowly towards the oblivious rabbit, getting ready to pounce. Just as the fox leapt into the air to catch his prey, he realized the rabbit was hopping right towards a hunter's trap. The fox tried to change course mid-leap but it was too late - he landed right into the hidden snare. While the fox struggled to free himself, the rabbit hopped happily away, having avoided danger by carefully looking where he was going before leaping forward.

fable1: A boy came across a pitcher filled with candy and, wanting to have some for himself, stuck his hand inside it. He grasped as much candy as he could in his fist, but found himself unable to get his hand out again, as his fist would not fit through the narrow neck of the pitcher. This caused him to break out in tears of frustration and disappointment. A passerby noticed the crying child and advised him to take out less candy, since that would allow him to relax his fist and draw out his hand more easily.
fable2: The young bird was eager to leave the nest and take his first flight. He stretched his wings as far as they would go and leapt from the tree branch. However, he had not yet built up enough strength in his small wings. As he frantically flapped, he began tumbling down through the air. The fall seemed endless as the ground raced up to meet him. He desperately tried to flap harder to break his fall, but his efforts were in vain. Crashing helplessly into the grass, the young bird realized he should have taken just a short hop to start. After recovering his breath, he resolved to try flying again, but one small step at a time.

fable1: A war between birds and beasts was about to break out, and the bat was unsure which side she should join. The birds asked her to help them, to which the bat replied: "Iâ€™m a beast.". Later, beasts passed by underneath her nest and offered her to join them, instead. "Iâ€™m a bird.", the bat insisted. Before things could get worse, diplomacy prevailed and a conflict was avoided. To celebrate the truce, the bat tried to join the festivities of the birds, who quickly turned against her. She then attempted to join the beasts' celebrations, but they, too, drove her away.
fable2: A fox lived on the edge of the forest. He was not fully a forest animal, nor was he a farm animal. The forest animals shunned him for spending too much time on the farm. The farm animals avoided him because he lived too close to the forest. Feeling lonely, the fox tried to make friends with both groups. But neither trusted him fully. Before long, the fox had no real friends left. Both groups rejected the fox for not fully belonging to their world. The fox learned that to have friends, you must commit to one place.

fable1: At a country fair, one of the performers amused the townsfolk by mimicking the cries of various farm animals. To finish his act, he squeaked very much like a pig would, making the audience wonder if he really had a piglet on stage. One of the spectators, however, was unimpressed. "You call that a pigâ€™s squeak? It sounds nothing like that! Come back here tomorrow and Iâ€™ll prove you wrong." The next day, the man went up the stage as promised, and squeaked so terribly that the audience booed and threw stones at him in protest. Protecting himself, the man exclaimed: "You fools, look at what youâ€™re booing!" and revealed a little piglet whose ear he had been pinching to produce the squeals.
fable2: A nightingale sang beautifully in the forest every night. The other birds loved to hear her song. One day a raven tried to imitate the nightingale's song but croaked horribly. The other birds laughed and booed at the raven's singing. The next night when the nightingale sang her lovely song again, the birds jeered and heckled her. They said "Your song is awful, not like the raven's at all!" The nightingale was confused and hurt. She realized the birds preferred an imitation over the real thing. So she flew away and never sang in the forest again.

fable1: An elderly lion was rapidly approaching his end and laid down in his cave, struggling to breath. Seeing him in such a dire shape, other animals approached him, drawing closer the weaker he got. Having made sure that he would not be able to defend himself, the animals decided to pay him back for all the grievances he caused them throughout his life. Thus, the boar tore into his body with her tusks and the bull impaled him on his horns. Lastly, even the donkey, feeling himself safe from any retribution, turned his tail to the lion and kicked him in the face.
fable2: The old lion had ruled the savannah for many years. Now weak and near death, he rested beneath a shady tree. Seeing this, the hyenas began to gather. They mocked the frail lion and laughed at his demise. "Not so mighty now!" the hyenas cackled. The lion said nothing. He simply lay still, gazing steadily at the hyenas with tired but dignified eyes. Ashamed, the hyenas looked away and slunk into the grass. When majesty falls, only cowards insult.

fable1: A knight, wearing a wig to conceal his baldness, went hunting. As he approached the forest, a sudden gust of wind swept the wig from his head, causing laughter to ring out from his companions. The knight himself started to laugh, as well, joking that it is no surprise that the hairpiece would abandon him, since it wouldnâ€™t even stay on the head of the man who grew it in the first place.
fable2: The peacock was known across the land for his beautiful, colorful feathers. He strutted around the farm every day, fanning his tail to show off. One day a storm came, with heavy winds. The proud peacock refused to take shelter and continued strutting. A strong gust blew, ruffling his feathers. When it passed, the peacock looked down to see his tail had lost all its colors. Now dull and brown, he tried to hide, but everyone saw the once-vain bird brought down. From then on, the peacock was much humbler.

fable1: A dog was pacing around in the barn, growling and snapping at the cows and thus preventing them from eating the hay that their owner left for them. Annoyed, one of the cows said to her sisters: "How selfish this dog is! He canâ€™t eat the hay, so he puts in all this effort to prevent us from enjoying it."
fable2: The fox gazed longingly at the plump, juicy grapes hanging high on the vine. He was hungry after a long day of hunting, and the grapes looked delicious. The fox jumped up towards the grapes, but they were just out of reach. He tried again and again, leaping as high as he could, but he could not reach them. Exhausted from jumping, the fox gave up and walked away, remarking, "Those grapes are probably sour anyway." Deep down, the fox knew the grapes were sweet and ripe. He was simply jealous that the grapes were beyond his grasp, so he convinced himself they must not be worth having after all.

fable1: A charcoal-burner, who practiced his trade in his own backyard, asked his friend if he would like to come and live with him. His friend, a launderer by profession, said in response: "This would be impossible, as whatever I wheaten would soon be turned black by your charcoal."
fable2: The north wind and the sun were arguing about who was stronger. The north wind boasted that he could make a traveler remove his coat. However hard the north wind blew, the traveler only wrapped his coat tighter. The sun then gently warmed the air and shone brightly on the traveler. Feeling the sun's warmth, the traveler happily took off his coat. Though the wind blustered and blew, the traveler was unmoved by his coldness. But the sun's gentle warmth was irresistible. The north wind had to admit that force is not the way to change minds. Kindness and understanding will attract others.

fable1: The rabbits, tired of being so timid and scared all of the time, decided to collectively end their lives by jumping off a tall cliff into a deep lake below. As their large group approached the edge of the cliff, the toads living on the banks of the lake became alarmed by the sound of their feet and quickly fled to safety. Observing the flight of the toads, one of the rabbits ordered the others to stop: "Wait, my friends! Maybe we should not go through with our plan, afer all, as there are clearly creatures who are even more easily scared than we are."
fable2: A young rabbit was sad that he did not have long ears like the other rabbits. He complained to his mother every day about his small ears. One day, a fox attacked their burrow. The mother rabbit heard the fox coming with her long ears and hid with her son. But the fox grabbed the young rabbit's small ears and pulled him from their hiding place. The mother rabbit got away safely thanks to her long ears. As the fox carried the young rabbit away, he realized he should have been grateful for his small ears rather than envious of his mother's.

fable1: "Papa," said the small toad to the larger one sitting by the side of a pond, "Yesterday, I came across a huge monster! It was the size of a mountain, had giant horns and a long tail, as well as hoofs that were split in two." "Donâ€™t be alarmed, child", replied the older toad, "that was just an oxen. There are many of those around the farms. Itâ€™s not nearly as big as you say, either. Indeed, I could make myself just as big as him. Let me show you." Having said that, he inhaled a lot of air and blew himself out. "Was he as big as I am now?", he asked his son. "No, he was much bigger than that!" replied the smaller toad. The father drew in even more air, and asked again if the oxen had been as big as he now was. "Even bigger than this, father!" was the reply. So the toad took one last deep breath and burst with a loud pop.
fable2: A fox was known across the forest for his cleverness. He outsmarted other animals daily and grew quite proud. One day he challenged a lion, certain his wit could best brute strength. At first the fox dodged the lion's attacks with ease. But his hubris led him to taunt and tease the great beast. Angered, the lion pounced with lightning speed. The fox tried to flee but was too slow. In one fatal swipe, the boastful fox met his end. The other animals shook their heads, knowing such arrogance would be the fox's undoing.

fable1: A farmer was sowing hemp seeds in his field, while around him birds were searching for food to pick off the ground. Among the birds was a single magpie, who warned the others to pick up every single one of the hemp seeds or they would regret not having done so. However, the other birds ignored her warning. Soon, the hemp grew up and was turned into cord, from which the farmer made nets to capture many of the birds that didnâ€™t listen to the magpie.
fable2: A farmer was working in his field when he noticed a small patch of weeds sprouting up. He thought about pulling them out, but they seemed so tiny and harmless that he decided to leave them be. Over time the weeds grew larger and spread across the field, choking out the farmer's crops. Soon his once bountiful field was overrun with tangling vines and thorns. The farmer regretted not uprooting those first few tiny weeds when he had the chance. Now they had grown into a mess he could hardly control, and his harvest was ruined.

fable1: In a war between mice and cats, the cats were always victorious. The mice assumed that the reason for their defeats was the lack of military leadership to command them and improve their morale. Thus, they elected those among them known for their heritage, strength, and wisdom as their leaders, as well as those who were the bravest fighters, to train up the mouse army. Once the mice completed their drills and felt sufficiently disciplined, they challenged the cats to another battle. Prior to the engagement, the newly elected mouse generals bound straws around their heads to be better seen by their troops on the battlefield. Yet despite all the preparations, the cats emerged victorious yet again, quickly routing the mice who retreated to their holes. The generals, however, could not fit inside the holes due to their headdress and were eaten by the cats as a result.
fable2: The lion was king of the jungle. All the animals respected and honored him. One day, a cunning fox decided he wanted to be king instead. He told lies about the lion to the other animals, saying he was cruel and unfair. Many animals turned against the lion and refused to honor him anymore. This made the lion very angry. He roared ferociously and chased the fox out of the jungle. From then on, the lion had to constantly fight to maintain his throne. The more he was honored as king, the more dangerous his position became.

fable1: Soaring through the air on a hot Summer day, the sparrow was nearly dying of thirst, when he saw a bottle of water painted on a signboard. Confusing the picture for the real thing, he flew towards the bottle with much speed and smashed against the board, injuring himself gravely. With both wings broken by the impact, he fell to the ground, but was caught by a passerby.
fable2: An eager hare challenged a wise old tortoise to a race. Confident he could easily outrun the slow tortoise, the hare darted off at top speed. After running far ahead, the overzealous hare decided to take a nap mid-race. When the hare awoke, he was shocked to see the tortoise slowly plodding past the finish line. The tortoise had quietly and steadily continued on his way while the hare wasted time resting on his early lead. Though swift, the impulsive hare learned the hard way that racing ahead without care leads to defeat.

fable1: Walking through a vineyard, a hungry raccoon saw a cluster of ripe, dark grapes hanging from a vine just out of his reach. Try as he might, the raccoon was unable to grab the grapes and soon gave up, exhausted. As he walked away from the vine, he said to himself: "These grapes are sour anyway, and not nearly ripe enough.", to hide his disappointment.
fable2: A hungry fox spotted a bunch of ripe grapes hanging high on a vine. He jumped and stretched his neck to reach them, but could not. He tried again and again, but the grapes remained just out of reach. Finally, the fox turned up his nose. "Those grapes are probably sour anyway," he said, and walked away. The fox consoled himself that he did not actually want grapes that were so hard to reach. But in his heart he knew the truth - he was simply bitter that the grapes were beyond his grasp.

fable1: Having been bitten by a rabid dog, a man went to search for someone who may heal him. Learning about his injury, a friend of his advised him to dip a piece of bread into the blood from his wound and feed it to the dog who bit him, as this would surely cure him. The bite victim laughed at this suggestion, saying: "Why would I do something like that? It would be like inviting every dog in the village to bite me."
fable2: A farmer worked hard to grow a bountiful crop of corn. When it ripened, flocks of crows descended on his field and began eating his corn. Instead of scaring the crows away, the kindly farmer set out food to feed them, hoping they would be satisfied and leave his crop alone. But the more he fed the crows, the more they invaded his field, having grown accustomed to the free food. Soon the crows had devoured all the farmer's corn while he helplessly watched his hard work disappear. The hungry crows still lingered in the barren fields in case the farmer took pity on them again.

fable1: The rabbit was a very popular animal and many of the forest creatures claimed to be her friends. One day, she heard the sound of dogs approaching from a distance which scared her greatly, as it was rabbit hunting season. Thus, she decided to escape them with the help of her many friends. First, she asked the horse to carry her to safety. The horse, however, refused his help, since he had work to do and felt sure that the rabbit would be helped by her other friends. Next, she asked the oxen to drive away the dogs away with his mighty horns, but he, too, refused to help, saying that he had already made plans with a lady friend of his. "The ram will certainly help you", he said, before turning away from the rabbit. The ram refused to help, as well, since the same dogs were known to attack sheep as well as rabbits. Almost out of time and options, the rabbit finally asked the calf for his help, but the young animal was uncomfortable with accepting such responsibility, seeing as so many adults declined to take on the task. Soon enough, the dogs arrived in the forest, but by then the rabbit had run away without anyoneâ€™s assistance.
fable2: Jackson was the most popular kid in school. He had hundreds of friends and got invited to every party. But when he got sick and missed a week of school, not one person texted to see how he was doing. When Jackson returned, he realized that although he was surrounded by people, he didn't have any real friends who cared about him. So he stopped trying to be friends with everyone and focused on building a few meaningful friendships. In the end, Jackson discovered it's better to have a few loyal friends than many superficial ones.

fable1: A man owned two dogs - one to help him hunt and one to keep him company at home. After each successful hunt, he gave the house dog a large portion of the spoils, which irritated the hunting dog. Thus, the hunting dog said to the house dog: "It frustrates me that I have to work so hard to chase down the prey, while you get to enjoy the fruits of my labor without having contributed to the hunt.". To that, the house dog replied: "Do not blame me, but blame our master, instead. After all, he hasnâ€™t taught me how to work for my food, but raised me to depend on others for my sustenance."
fable2: A young fawn lived alone in the forest after hunters had killed his mother. The other animals shunned him, believing he must have the same violent nature as she did. One day, the fawn fell into a ravine and was stuck. The animals passed him by, unwilling to help. Finally, a wise old owl came upon the scene. Seeing the fawn's gentle eyes, he realized the young one was not at all like his mother. The owl flew down and lifted the fawn to safety with his talons. From then on, the animals accepted the fawn for who he was, not who his mother had been. The owl knew it was unfair to judge someone based on their parents' flaws.

fable1: It happened once that a tiger fell in love with a young woman and proposed a marriage to her parents. Understandably, the old couple didnâ€™t want to give up their daughter to the tiger, but also didnâ€™t want to anger the dangerous predator. Thus, they offered him a compromise: "While we are very honored by you offer, we are afraid that you might injure our daughter when showing your affection, as she is young and tender. We would feel much safer and happily reconsider your proposal if you had your teeth and claws removed to reduce the possible dangers to her." The tiger, blind with love, promptly had his claws cut and teeth taken out. When he next met the parents of his beloved, they laughed at him and simply ignored him, as he no longer posed any threat.
fable2: Deep in the forest lived a ferocious bear. All the animals feared him and stayed far away. One day, a kind rabbit approached the lonely bear. Though scared, she offered him friendship. The bear was surprised by her gentle nature. Over time, the bear's heart softened as the rabbit's affection soothed his wild spirit. Soon the bear's growls turned to laughter as the unlikely pair became inseparable friends. Where once there was only isolation and fear, now compassion and love reigned.

fable1: A singing bird, confined to a cage hanging outside a window, made a habit of only singing at night, when no other bird was awake. One night, a bat was flying through the area and heard the birdâ€™s song. Curious, he asked the bird why she sang at night, unlike the other birds. The bird replied: "When I last sang during the daytime, my voice attracted a birdcatcher who trapped me and placed me inside this cage. Ever since then, I only sing at night." Puzzled, the bat replied: "What difference does it make, now that youâ€™re a prisoner? If you had only sung at night before you were caught, you would still have your freedom."
fable2: The fox noticed that the grapes in the vineyard were ripening. He decided he must find a way to get the delicious grapes. He thought and thought about how to reach them, devising plan after plan. Finally, the day came when the grapes were perfectly ripe. The fox snuck into the vineyard, only to find all the grapes had already been harvested. Looking around the empty vines, the fox realized he had spent so much time preparing he had missed his chance. With his stomach still empty, the fox slowly walked away.

fable1: A donkey heard the melodic chirping of grasshoppers while passing through a meadow and wanted to become just as talented of a musician as they were. Thus, he asked them what food they were eating, to have such pretty voices. The grasshoppers replied that they eat nothing but dew. In his wisdom, the donkey tried to survive on dew alone, but soon starved to death.
fable2: A hungry fox spotted a juicy rabbit in a field. He licked his lips and crept up slowly to pounce. But the fox was careless and stepped on a twig, snapping it loudly. The rabbit's ears perked up at the sound and he hopped away to safety just in time. The fox chased after the rabbit but it was too fast. Out of breath, the fox returned home with an empty stomach, cursing himself for not being more careful and quiet when he had the chance. From then on, the fox was more cautious when hunting, realizing that acting foolishly could make him miss his opportunity.

fable1: On their journey along the seashore, a group of travellers climbed on top of a tall cliff, and spotted an object approaching them in the distance, believing it to be a ship. They decided to stay and watch it enter the harbor, but as it came closer, the object started to resemble a small boat, rather than a large ship. As it finally reached the beach, driven by the wind, it turned out to be nothing more than a bundle of sticks. Disappointed, one of the travellers remarked: "We have waited here for no reason, as there was nothing to see here other than a pile of driftwood."
fable2: The young hare dreamed of becoming the fastest animal in the forest. He spent his days imagining the admiration of the other creatures as he sped by. He pictured the wind rushing through his fur as he raced through the trees. The hare trained relentlessly, pushing his body to its limits. Finally the day arrived for the great race that would prove his speed. With anticipation the hare crouched at the starting line. At the sound of the whistle he sprang forward with all his might. But his legs had not yet grown into the powerful limbs he had envisioned. Try as he might, the hare just could not run as fast as he had hoped.

fable1: Witnessing his might, a hawk proposed an alliance to a tiger, so that they may help each other with hunting their prey. The tiger had no objections, but required some proof of the hawkâ€™s good intentions, saying: "How can I trust someone to be a friend who could simply fly away from this alliance whenever it suits him?"
fable2: A hungry fox came across a vineyard filled with ripe, juicy grapes. As he admired them from outside the fence, he began to crave the sweet grapes. The fox looked around and saw that the farmer was nowhere in sight. He thought if he could just get over the fence, he could sneak a few grapes to satisfy his hunger. The fox jumped up and clung to the fence with his front paws. But as he tried to swing his back legs up, the fence wobbled and shook, threatening to collapse under his weight. The fox let go and landed back on the ground, no closer to the grapes than when he started. He realized the flimsy fence could not support him. The fox trotted off, his hunger unsatisfied but having learned his lesson.

fable1: A donkey was enjoying the sun in the company of a rooster, when a famished tiger approached them with the intention to find his next meal. Before the tiger could attack the donkey, the rooster crowed loudly, scaring the predator and causing him to flee as fast as he could. Seeing how terrified the tiger was, the donkey decided to chase after him, intending to kick him for threatening his life. After they ran a long distance, the tiger turned around and pounced on the donkey, who soon perished from his wounds.
fable2: The hare was proud of his speed. He boasted to the other animals that no one could outrun him. One day he challenged the tortoise to a race, certain he would win. When the race began, the overconfident hare darted ahead, then decided to take a nap midway, assuming he was so far ahead that he could not lose. While the hare slept, the slow but steady tortoise plodded past him and reached the finish line first. The hare awoke and raced to the finish as fast as he could, but it was too late. Though the hare was swift, his false confidence in an easy victory led to his misfortune in losing the race.

fable1: Chopping down a tree, a woodsman accidentally dropped his ax into the nearby lake. As the lake was very deep, he was unable to retrieve his tool and sat down on the bank, mourning its loss. Suddenly, Hermes appeared before the woodsman and asked him about the reason for his sadness. After learning about his misfortune, Hermes retrieved a golden ax from the lake, asking the woodsman if it was his. Hearing the woodsman say that it was not, Hermes retrieved a second ax from the lake, one made of silver. The woodsman again said that this was not his tool. Finally, Hermes pulled out the woodmanâ€™s ax from the water, who was overjoyed and identified the tool as his own. To reward his honesty, Hermes gave the woodsman all three axes to keep. Some time later, the woodsman told his friends about his encounter with Hermes. One of them headed straight to the same lake, threw his own ax into it, and waited for Hermes to arrive. As before, the god recovered a golden ax from the lake first. Driven by greed, the woodsmanâ€™s friend claimed it to be his right away. Upset by his dishonesty, Hermes took away the golden ax way from him and disappeared, without recovering the manâ€™s own tool.
fable2: A fox was out searching for food one day when he came across a vineyard full of ripe, delicious grapes. As he approached, the owner of the vineyard appeared and warned the fox not to steal any of his grapes. The fox promised he wouldn't touch them. As soon as the owner left, the tempted fox jumped into the vineyard to grab some grapes. He ate so many that he became sick. The owner returned and saw the poor fox rolling on the ground in pain. The owner shook his head and said, "You should have been honest with me. Now you see that honesty is always the best policy."

fable1: A rabbit, who was a fast runner, once made fun of a tortoise for her slow and measured gait. The tortoise laughed, saying: "As fast as you may be, I will easily beat you in a race." The rabbit quickly accepted the challenge, thinking that it would be impossible for him to lose and asked the raccoon to choose the course and decide on the goal. On the day of the race, the two competitors started running together. But while the tortoise never stopped, slowly and steadily advancing toward the goal, the rabbit laid down by the wayside to take a nap and fell fast asleep. When he finally awoke, he rushed to the goal, but the tortoise has already crossed the finish line by then.
fable2: There was once a turtle who wanted to race a hare. Though the hare was very fast, the turtle knew he could win with persistence. When the race began, the hare sprinted ahead as expected. But the turtle plodded along at his steady pace. Lap after lap he stayed focused, never stopping to rest. Though far behind at first, he eventually began gaining ground. By the final stretch the hare was exhausted from exerting himself. But the turtle kept his same steady pace, passing the hare just before the finish line to win. Though slow, the turtle's perseverance paid off in the end.

fable1: An angler, after spending the whole day fishing, only caught one small fish. The fish begged him to spare her, saying: "I am far too small to make a filling meal for you right now. Let me go and I will grow, so that you can catch me later when I can satisfy your hunger." The angler smiled and replied: "I think I will keep you, little fish. I have you now, but I may not be able to catch you later."
fable2: A hungry fox came across a vineyard full of ripe, juicy grapes. He licked his chops at the prospect of feasting on the bountiful harvest. But the vines were too high for him to reach. After many failed attempts to jump up and grab the grapes, the tired and frustrated fox gave up. As he sulked away, head hung low, he stumbled upon a dropped bunch of grapes on the ground. Though not as plentiful as the harvest on the vines, the few grapes he could easily reach were far more valuable to the hungry fox than the feast that remained out of grasp. So he gobbled them up gratefully before continuing on his way.

fable1: Once upon a time, there was a wealthy man who hid all of his gold at the foot of an apple tree in his garden. But every now and then he would dig it up to admire his wealth. A thief soon noticed his strange behaviour and, after finding out the location of the gold, dug it up one night and took it for himself. When next visiting his hoard, the wealthy man only found an empty hole, which caused him to cry out in anguish. Hearing his cries, one of the manâ€™s neighbors asked what caused him such distress and thus learned about the gold hoard. "Did you ever use your gold for anything?", the neighbor asked. When the man replied that he only admired it, the neighbor said: "You may as well admire the empty hole, as it will accomplish just as much."
fable2: A miser lived alone in a small house. Though he had amassed a great fortune over the years, he lived very simply. Each day he counted his gold coins over and over. One day, thieves broke in while the miser slept. They took all his gold and fled into the night. When the miser awoke, he saw that all his wealth was gone. But he simply went about his day as usual, eating plain food and sitting alone in his house. For though the miser had been rich, he had never used his wealth for anything. So its disappearance changed nothing about how he lived.

fable1: A fox was playing with her pups one sunny morning when she saw a lioness doting on her only cub. "Why care so much about a single cub?", inquired the fox, adding: "See how many babies I have and try to imagine just how proud of a mother I am!" The lioness responded with a sharp look and an upturned nose, saying only: "Yes, you may have many children, but they are only foxes. My child, on the other hand, is a lion."
fable2: A young fox was hunting for his dinner. He came across a flock of slow, fat sheep. Excited, he thought "With so many to choose from, I'll eat well tonight!" But when he pounced, the sheep scattered and ran too fast for him to catch any. Disappointed, the fox kept searching. He soon spotted a lone, injured rabbit. Though small, it could not escape. The fox caught the rabbit easily and enjoyed a tasty, quality meal.

fable1: A birdcatcher didnâ€™t have much success that day and was about to have a small dinner of herbs and vegetables, when a friend came to visit. Since his traps were empty, he decided to kill a partridge that he used as a decoy. The bird begged him to spare her, saying that he wouldnâ€™t be able to catch birds in the future without her help, nor fall asleep to her relaxing chirps. The birdcatcher saw reason in her words and instead decided to butcher a young rooster whom he kept in his yard. The rooster, too, pleaded with his owner, saying that without his crawling, the birdcatcher wouldnâ€™t know  when to collect his traps, nor would he be able to rise early in the morning. Having heard him out, the birdcatcher finally said: "Your words make sense. However, my friend and I are hungry and must have our meal."
fable2: The forest was quiet as the hungry wolf crept through the trees, stalking a deer. Winter had been long and food was scarce. The wolf's pack needed to eat soon or they would starve. As the deer bent its head to drink from a stream, the wolf seized his chance. With a snarl he leaped from the brush, his jaws closing on the deer's neck. The deer cried out and struggled but it was too late. Dragging his prize back through the silent trees, the wolf thought only of his hungry pack waiting in their den. Necessity had demanded he hunt outside the pack's normal territory, but the law of survival left him no choice.

fable1: A tiger was stirred from his afternoon nap by a mouse running across his face. Angered, he grabbed the mouse with his paws and was about to snap her neck, when the mouse asked him for mercy. "If you spare me, I will make sure to return the favour in the future.", said the mouse. Amused by the notion of a mouse saving his life, the tiger laughed and let her go. A couple of days later, the tiger wandered into a trap laid by a group of hunters, who bound him with strong ropes to a tree. As the tiger roared in frustration, the mouse recognized his voice and bit through the ropes with her sharp teeth, thus saving him from a certain death.
fable2: A young boy was walking home from school when he saw a butterfly struggling to emerge from its chrysalis. Though late for dinner, the boy paused to help free the butterfly. With his gentle aid, the butterfly emerged and flew off into the sunset. The boy smiled and continued home, his heart warmed. The next day at school, the boy was surprised when a classmate he barely knew thanked him for his kindness. Though the boy had thought his small act went unnoticed, he realized it had meant the world to the one who saw. From that day on, the two became the best of friends.

fable1: Upset at the leisurely life of the stomach, other members of the body rose up against him, accusing him to do nothing but rest and enjoy the food, while they toil to satisfy its wants and needs. To prove their point, they resolved not to provide any more assistance to the stomach, which ended up hurting the entire body, as it was now deprived of the neccessary nutrients. The hands, feet, ears, eyes, and mouth eventually recognized their error, but by then it was too late.
fable2: The forest was home to many animals. There were deer, rabbits, birds, and more. One day a great storm came through the forest, knocking down trees and branches. The animals were scared, but knew they must work together. The deer carried the smaller animals to safety. The birds gathered twigs for new nests. The rabbits dug holes to provide shelter. Though each animal had a different role, they worked side by side to repair their home. When the sun came out, the forest was whole again.

fable1: A boy, nearly drowning in a river after having exerted himself too much, called out to a passerby for help. Instead of reaching out and pulling the boy ashore, the passerby scolded him for his thoughtlessness, telling the boy that he should have been more careful. The boy replied while trying to stay afloat: "Please, help me first and scold me later all you want!"
fable2: A young bird fell from his nest onto the ground below. Though flightless, he was determined to get back to his home. He called out for help from the other animals, asking them how he might reach his nest again. The wise old owl said "Flap your wings harder." The nimble squirrel said "Climb the tree using your claws." The powerful bear said "Build a ladder out of branches." Though they offered much advice, none could provide the aid the little bird truly needed. And so he remained stranded, with no way to achieve his goal alone.
